datasets.summary: Population estimates data by sex and single year of age for countries, regions and smaller geographic breakdowns

datasets.title: Population data collection
datasets.summary: Population estimates data overview by age group for the United Kingdom, England and Wales, and Great Britain

datasets.title: Population for Local Authorities
datasets.summary: Components of population change for countries; regions, counties and smaller geographic breakdowns

statsBulletins.headline1: The population of the UK grew to 64.1 million in mid-2013, representing a gain of 400,600 (0.63%) over the previous year mid-2012.
statsBulletins.headline2: This means that the UK’s population has increased by around 5 million since 2001, and by more than 10 million since 1964.
statsBulletins.headline3: Natural change (births minus deaths) contributed slightly more than net international migration to the population gain in the year.
statsBulletins.title: Annual Mid-year Population Estimates, 2013
statsBulletins.summary: Estimates of the usual resident population in the United Kingdom and its constituent countries as at 30 June 2013.

title: Population estimates
summary: Annual estimates of the size of the UK “usually resident population” are calculated at the mid-year point (30 June). The ONS compile and publish the UK estimates using estimates for England and Wales (produced by ONS directly), estimates for Scotland (produced by National Records of Scotland) and estimates for Northern Ireland (produced by the Northern Ireland Statistics & Research Agency).

breadcrumb.title: Home
breadcrumb.summary: The UK's largest independent producer of official statistics and the recognised national statistical institute of the UK.

breadcrumb.title: People, population and community
breadcrumb.summary: Statistics in this area tell us a lot about the people living in the UK. From the level and growth in the population, to data and analysis on how households spend their money. We also have data on crime, divorce, diseases and religion here as well as much more. These statistics have a wide range of users and uses and they help us build a detailed picture of the country we live in.

breadcrumb.title: Population and migration
breadcrumb.summary: Population and migration statistics describe the size, age, sex structure and geographic distribution of the UK population. They also consider changes to the UK population and the factors driving these changes. These statistics have a wide range of uses; they are used by central government, local government and the health sector for planning, resource allocation and managing the economy. Additionally, they are used by a wide range of people such as market researchers, academics and those in special interest groups.
